newsitem.title: ANTIGUA AND BARBUDA: Antiguan government investigates six banks.
newsitem.headline: Antiguan government investigates six banks.

text.p: Antiguan government officials said on Friday they were investigating six offshore banks with Russian and Ukrainian links that U.S. officials claimed were being run as money laundering operations.
"It became apparent that the offshore banking act was a very weak one," said Wrenford Ferrance, special adviser on drugs and money laundering policy to Antigua's prime minister, Lester Bird.
"There were a lot of loopholes and these banks were pretty unregulated," Ferrance told a news conference at the bi-annual summit of the Caribbean Community Heads of Government.

He said the prime minister, after prodding by Washington, ordered an investigation a year ago into Antigua's banking system. The investigation concluded that relatively few of the island's offshore banks could be regarded as legitimate.
Ferrance said the government had identified six of 59 offshore banks registered in Antigua as having Russian or Ukrainian links.

Ferrance said the island's offshore bank inspectorate was preparing to shut down five of six of those banks "due to irregularities in their operations." He did not indicate which banks were being forced to close on the island.
He said the government also declared a moratorium on new offshore bank applications until a new, stricter law could be tabled in parliament later this year.
Antigua first marketed itself as an offshore banking center in 1983, hoping to diversify its economy, which is heavily dependent on tourism.
According to the finance ministry, fees paid by offshore banks last year totaled $1.6 million, far less than the $30 million to $40 million Bird says the sector is capable of producing.

"We've gotten a bum rap," Bird told reporters, referring to the island's reputation for being a haven for dirty money, pointing to the fact that the majority of Antigua's offshore institutions were owned and operated by Americans.
Bird said Antigua had asked the British government to send a permanent representative to Antigua to help monitor the island's banking sector.

Ferrance said that since the early 1990s, a growing number of offshore banks had been registered in Antigua. Recently, U.S. and British officials urged Antiguan authorities to tighten up the system, alleging the so-called Russian mafia was laundering hundreds of millions of dollars through its offshore banks there.
